review.title: Approximating the Bethe partition function
review.abstract: When belief propagation (BP) converges, it does so to a stationary point of the Bethe free energy $F$, and is often strikingly accurate. However, it may converge only to a local optimum or may not converge at all. An algorithm was recently introduced for attractive binary pairwise MRFs which is guaranteed to return an $\epsilon$-approximation to the global minimum of $F$ in polynomial time provided the maximum degree $\Delta=O(\log n)$, where $n$ is the number of variables. Here we significantly improve this algorithm and derive several results including a new approach based on analyzing first derivatives of $F$, which leads to performance that is typically far superior and yields a fully polynomial-time approximation scheme (FPTAS) for attractive models without any degree restriction. Further, the method applies to general (non-attractive) models, though with no polynomial time guarantee in this case, leading to the important result that approximating $\log$ of the Bethe partition function, $\log Z_B=-\min F$, for a general model to additive $\epsilon$-accuracy may be reduced to a discrete MAP inference problem. We explore an application to predicting equipment failure on an urban power network and demonstrate that the Bethe approximation can perform well even when BP fails to converge.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 140 1.00 44v1 [cs.LG] 3 0D ec2 01When faith multiplication (BP) converges, this occurs to a stationary point of the fact-free energy F and is often strikingly accurate. However, it can only converge to a local optimum or not converge at all. For attractive binary pairs of MRFs, an algorithm has recently been introduced that guarantees that it returns to a global minimum of F in polynomial time, provided the maximum degree ∆ = O (log n), where n is the number of variables. Here, we greatly improve this algorithm and derive several results, including a new approach based on the analysis of initial derivatives of F, resulting in a performance that is typically far superior and yields a fully polynomial time approximation scheme (FPTAS) for attractive models without any limitation. Furthermore, the method applies to general (non-attractive) models, although in this case polynomial convergence does not guarantee the BP's ability to reduce the polynomial function, which in this case guarantees the time convergence of BP.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The first two problems are linked (a problem used in many areas such as speech recognition, systems biology, and computer vision): a set of variables and a score function are defined in such a way that the probability of configuring variables is proportional to the value of the score, in terms of the sum of scores in all possible constellations, in a way that defines a topology of the variables; three central problems are: 1. the evaluation of the partition function Z, which is the sum of scores across all possible constellations, and 2. the normalization of the constants for the probability distribution; 2. the calculation of the probability distribution of a given substance in a given substance; 3. the evaluation of the partition function Z, which is the task of the partition, which is the task of the constant of the constant of the constant; 3. the task of the constant of the variables, the maximum probability of the distribution.

sections.heading: 1.1 Contribution and Summary
sections.text: The overall approach is to construct a sufficient network of discretised points so that the optimal mesh point q * guarantees F (q *) within the true optimum. The new, first derivative approach generally leads to a much coarser but still sufficient mesh, and also allows adaptive methods to focus points in regions where F can vary quickly. Separately, we are also refining the second derivative method (Weller & Jebara, 2013a) to derive a method that is suitable for very small but sufficient points. We will then consider how best to solve the resulting discrete optimization problem, which can vary rapidly in regions where F can.

sections.heading: 1.1.1 Structure of the overall algorithm
sections.text: Input: Parameters {θi, Wij} for a general binary pair-wise MRF (format conversion using the repair parameterization of § 2.1 if required) and a desired accuracy. 1. Pre-processing by calculating boundaries {Ai, Bi} at the locations of minima (see § 2.4).2. Construct a sufficient network using one of the methods in this essay. In fact, all approaches are fast so that several can be used, then the most efficient network is selected. 2Computing e.g. is at least PPAD or PLS-hard in general, as it requires not only a fixed point, but also the global minimizer (Shin, 2013; Daskalakis & Papadimitriou, 2011).3. Attempt to solve the resulting problem of multi-label MAP inference, see § 5.4.

sections.heading: 1.2 Related work
sections.text: Methods such as CCCP (Yuille, 2002) or UPS (Teh & Welling, 2002) are guaranteed to converge to a local minimum of free Bethe energy, but this may be far from the global optimum. Previous work has derived a fully polynomial, randomized approximation scheme (FPRAS) for the actual partition function (Jerrum & Sinclair, 1993), but only if singleton potentials are uniform (i.e. a uniform external field) and the resulting runtime is high at O (Logn-2m3n11). Recently it has been demonstrated (Heinemann & Globerson, 2011) that models exist in such a way that the actual limit probability cannot possibly be the location of a minimum of free Bethe energy. Our work shows an interesting link between MAP inference techniques (NP-Hard) and the estimation of the partition function Z (# P-Hard).

sections.heading: 2.1 Input model specification
sections.text: We assume that an input model is given with singleton concepts θi as in (1), but with paired energy concepts given instead by − Wij2 xixj − Wij 2 (1 − xi) (1 − xj). In this format, the variation of Wij simply changes the degree of push / pull between i and j, without also changing the probability that each variable will be 0 or 1, as is the case with the format of (1). We assume that the maximum possible values W and T are known with | θi | ≤ T-i-V, and | Wij | ≤ W-V (i, j).

sections.heading: 2.2 Submodularity
sections.text: In our context, a pair of multi-label functions on a set of ordered labels is Xij = {1,.., Ki} · {1,.., Kj} submodular iff, x, y, f (x-y) + f (x-y) ≤ f (x-x) + f (y), where for x = (x1, x2) and y = (y1, y2), (x-y) = (min (x1, y1), min (x2, y2)) and (x-y) = (max (x1, y1), max (x2, y2)), for binary variables submodular energy is synonymous with attractiveness. The key property for us is that if all pair-wise cost functions are fij overMi × Mj from (5) multimodular, then the global discredited optimum is efficient based on charts (Schlesinger & Flach, 2006) > M is all discrete (if all).

sections.heading: 2.3 Flipping variables
sections.text: As in (Weller & Jebara, 2013a), we use the techniques below to reverse variables, i.e. we can look at a new model with variables {X ′ i}, where X ′ i = 1 − Xi for a selection of i. Turning a variable reverses the parity of all its incidental edges, which is so attractive ↔ repellent. Turning both ends of an edge leaves its parity unchanged.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 Flipping all variables
sections.text: Consider a new model with variables {X ′ i = 1 − Xi, i = 1,..., n} and the same edges. Instead of the parameters θi and Wij, those of the new model should be the values θ "i" and W "ij. Identify values so that the energies of all states are maintained up to a constants 4: E = − ichichichichichichichichichV θiXi − ichichichichichXiXjj = Konst − ichichichichichichichichichi (ichichichichichichichXi) − ichichichichichij (ichichichichichichiW) ichij (ichichichichichiXj).Matching coefficients result in W ′ ichij = Wijichi = − randomness (ichWij.6) If the original model was attractive, then the new model is also attractive.

sections.heading: 2.3.2 Flipping some variables
sections.text: Sometimes it is helpful to reverse only a subset of R V of the variables, which can be useful, for example, to make the model locally attractive around a variable, which can always be achieved by reversing only the neighbors to which it has a repulsive edge. Leave X ′ i = 1 − Xi if i-R, otherwise X ′ i = Xi for i-S, where S = V\ R. Leave Et = {edges with exact t ends in R = 0, 1, 2. As in 2.3.1, the solution for W ′ ij and θ ′ i is such that the energies remain unchanged up to a constant, W ′ ij = {Wij (i, j), E0, E2, − Wij (i, j), E1.

sections.heading: 2.5 Derivatives of F
sections.text: In (Welling & Tej, 2001), the first subderivatives of free Bethe energy are derived as follows: "F-Qi = -Qi + logQi, (8):" Qi = (1-Qi) di − 1qdi − 1i-J-N (i) "(qi − changij)," J-N (i) "(1 + communicij − qi)," Theorem 6 "(second derivatives for each edge, (Weller & Jebara, 2013a)," Theorem 7. "BBP" and "MK" are always methods that can converge quickly and be implemented in such a way that each iteration runs in O (m) time. "MK" takes a little longer, but can result in narrower limits. "" Qi-Qi "and" MK "are always methods that can converge quickly and be implemented in such a way that each iteration runs in O (m) time.

sections.heading: 3 NEW APPROACH
sections.text: We are developing a new approach to construct a sufficient mesh M by analyzing the limitations of the first derivatives of the F method, resulting in several attractive features: • For attractive models, we obtain an FPTAS with worst-case runtime O (= Li-3m3W 3) and no constraint on topology as required in (Weller & Jebara, 2013a). • Our sufficient mesh is typically coarser than the earlier method of (Weller & Jebara, 2013a), which leads to a much simpler subsequent MAP problem, unless it is very small. Here is the sum of the discretization points in each dimension, N = O (nmW). The earlier method, even after our improvements in § 4, forms a mesh with N = O (1 / 2n7 / 4) exp [1 + 2 (W + 2) + T))))).

sections.heading: 3.1 Refinements, adaptive methods
sections.text: Since the resulting problem of multilabel MAP inference is generally NP-hard (Shimony, 1994), it is helpful to minimize its size. As mentioned above, the determination of γi = еnDi, which we call the simple method, results in an adequate mesh, where | ∂ F ∂ qi | ≤ Di = Vi + Wi − logLi − logUi. However, since the boundary curves are monotonous at fUi ≥ 0 and fLi ≤ 0, a better boundary for the size of the derivative is often available by specifying Di = max {fUi (1 − Bi), − fLi (Ai)}.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 The minsum method
sections.text: We define Ni = the number of mesh points in dimension i, with the sum N = ∑ i-V-Ni and the product т = сi-V-Ni. For a fully attractive model, the resulting MAP problem can be solved in time O (N3) by diagram sections (Theorem 1, (Schlesinger & Flach, 2006; Greig et al., 1989; Goldberg & Tarjan, 1988), so it makes sense to minimize N. However, in other cases it is less clear what to minimize. To minimize N while ensuring that the mesh pattern is sufficient, we consider the distribution of possible values in dimension i as Si = 1 − Bi − Ai − and note Ni = 1 + Si2хi ², is required to cover the entire area.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Adaptive methods
sections.text: The previous methods are based on a bound Di for | ∂ F ∂ qi | over the entire range [Ai, 1 − Bi]. However, we can increase efficiency by using local boundaries to vary the mesh size over the entire range. A limitation on the maximum size of the derivative over any sub-range can be found by testing only − fLi at the lower end and fUi at the upper end. This can be improved by using the exact integral as in (14). First, constant proportions ki > 0 with [qi = 1] should be chosen. Next, the first (lowest) mesh point γ i 1 х Mii should be specified.

sections.heading: 4 REVISITING THE SECOND DERIVATIVE APPROACH
sections.text: We consider the second derivative approach applied in (Weller & Jebara, 2013a) (see there § 5). As here, the possible location of a global minimum q in the Bethe Box was first limited by specifying the maximum eigenvalue of the Hessian H from F somewhere within the Bethe Box, where it was necessary for all edges to be attractive. Then, a mesh of constant width was introduced in each dimension s.t. The closest mesh point q to q was farthest away in each dimension. Therefore, the Hessian H-2 spacing δ2 ≤ nγ2 and according to Taylor's theorem F (q-2) ≤ F (q-2) ≤ F (q-2) was calculated by limiting the maximum size of an element of H. Taking into account theorem 7, this involves a separate analysis of the diagonal Hii concepts that are positive and were limited by terms b and Hib, as well as by the limitations above the limitations (Hib) and not by the limitations of the Hib (Hib).

sections.heading: 4.1 Improved bound for an attractive model
sections.text: In essence, a more careful analysis allows a potentially smaller term in the counter and in the denominator to be cancelled before the limit, resulting in − Hij ≤ (αij 1 + αij) / η (1 − (αij 1 + αij) 2) (17) = O (eW (1 + х / 2) + T), resulting in an advantageous b = O (eW (1 + х / 2) + 2T) and vice versa b = B (max.

sections.heading: 4.2 Extending the second derivative approach to a general (non-attractive) model
sections.text: Interestingly, the theoretical limits that can be derived for а = max (a, b) take exactly the same form as for the purely attractive case, except that now − W ≤ Wij ≤ W, whereas previously it was required that 0 ≤ Wij ≤ W. Since it is a second derivative approach, the mesh size (measured by N, the total number of points added up over the dimensions) grows in the new first derivative approach as O (B − 1 / 2) and not as O (B − 1). In practice, however, the method of § 3 is much more efficient, especially in more difficult cases where n and W are above small values, unless it is very small. Details and derivatives can be found in the supplement.

sections.heading: 5 RESULTING MULTI-LABEL MAP
sections.text: After the calculation of a sufficient mesh, the solution of the problem of multi-label MAP inference on an MRF with the same topology as the initial model, where each Qi records values in Mi, remains. Generally, this is NP-hard (Shimony, 1994).

sections.heading: 5.1 Tractable cases
sections.text: If it occurs that all cost functions are submodular (as is always the case when the original model is fully attractive by Theorem 1), then, as already mentioned, it can be efficiently solved by diagram intersection methods based on solving a problem with maximum flow / min intersection on a related diagram, with the worst runtime O (N3) (Schlesinger & Flach, 2006; Greig et al., 1989; Goldberg & Tarjan, 1988). Using the BoykovKolmogorov algorithm (Boykov & Kolmogorov, 2004), performance is typically much faster and sometimes approaches O (N). This submodular setting is the only known problem class that can be solved for any topology. Alternatively, the topological limitation of limited tree width allows tractable conclusions (Pearl & Kolmogorov, 1988).

sections.heading: 5.2 All other cases
sections.text: Many different methods are available, see (Kappes et al., 2013) for a recent survey. Some, such as dual approaches, can provide a helpful limit, even if the optimum is not found. In fact, LP relaxation will take place in polynomial time and return an upper limit to logZB, which can be useful. A lower limit can be found from any discrete point, and this can be improved by local search methods. Also, note that the BBP limits Qi [Ai, 1 − Bi] apply to the entire Bethe field, but for a certain value of Qi, for example, then the BBP approach provides narrower limits for each of its neighbors j-N (i), which can be helpful in narrowing the solution space.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Persistent partial optimization approaches
sections.text: MQPBO (Kohli et al., 2008) and Kovtun's method (Kovtun, 2003) are examples of this class. Both consider LPrelaxations and run in polynomial time. In our context, output consists of setting ranges (which could be a point at best) for a subset of variables. If such ranges are returned, the strong persistence property ensures that each MAP solution meets the ranges. Therefore, they can be used to update {Ai, Bi} boundaries (increase the discredited range to the full continuous range, which may be covered by the endpoints), to calculate a new, smaller, sufficient mesh, and to repeat until no improvement is achieved.

sections.heading: 6 EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: As a first step in applying our algorithm to explore the usefulness of the global optimum of the Bethe approach, we consider here a setting in which LBP does not converge, but nevertheless achieves reasonable results.We aim to predict transformer failures in a power grid (Rudin et al., 2012). Because the real data is sensitive, our experiments use synthetic data to determine whether transformer i has failed or not. Each transformer has a failure probability on its own, which is represented by a singleton potential succi. However, when a transformer is connected in a network, a transformer can extend its failure to nearby nodes (as in the case of viral infection), since the edges in the network form associative dependencies. We assume that homogeneously attractive pairwise potentials are all transformers connected by an edge value, Wij-j = W.

sections.heading: 7 DISCUSSION & FUTURE WORK
sections.text: To our knowledge, we have derived the first approximation algorithm for logZB for a general binary pair-by-pair model, which is useful in practice and much more efficient than the previous method (Weller & Jebara, 2013a), although it can take a long time to solve large, closely related problems or if the coupling is high. We note from experiments carried out that the limits appear to be narrow, as we have found models where the optimum is executed more than 0.5 differently than when executed with B = 0.1. When applied to attractive models, we guarantee an FPTAS without limitations. Future work will include further improving the efficiency of the network, testing how it should be selected to simplify the subsequent discrete optimization problem, and exploring applications. Interesting approaches include using it as a subroutine in a dual decomposition approach for optimization via a narrower relativization of the 2002 marginal Cypal set, and the possibility of running iBP more quickly than the other types of polyps or Yuoros).

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank Kui Tang for helping with programming and David Sontag, Kui Tang, Nicholas Ruozzi and Tomaz Slivnik for helpful discussions. This material is based on work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant number 1117631.10.

sections.heading: APPENDIX: SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL FOR APPROXIMATING THE BETHE PARTITION FUNCTION
sections.text: Here we provide further details and corrections of some of the results in the main paper using the original numbering.

sections.heading: 4 REVISITING THE SECOND DERIVATIVE APPROACH
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Improved bound for an attractive model
sections.text: In this section, we improve the upper boundary by improving the boundary for attractive edges to derive an improved upper boundary to − Hij. Essentially, a more careful analysis allows a potentially small boundary in the number and denominator − − − to be removed before the boundary. Using Theorem 7, Equation (9) and Lemma 5, − Hij = (weighting) 1Tij − m (1 − M) 1 + 1 − M (1 − M) 1 + 1 − M (1 − M) 1 + 1 − M) [(1 − m) M − m (1 − M) (1 − M) (1 − M) (αij 1 + 1 ²) 2] = (αij 1 + 1 − m) M − m (1 − M − m) 1 + 1 − M (1 − M) 2 (18), with m = min (qi, qj), M = 1 − M = max (qi, qj) and qj (1), now we use the following result.

sections.heading: 4.2 Extending the second derivative approach to a general (non-attractive) model
sections.text: Here we extend the analysis of (Weller & Jebara, 2013a) by looking at repulsive edges to show that we can still calculate useful limits (which prove to be very similar to previous boundaries for attractive models) for a sufficient mesh size for a general binary pair-wise model. Our most important tool for dealing with a repulsive edge is to rotate the variable at one end (see § 2.3) to achieve an attractive edge, then we can apply previous results. As we denote the inverted model parameters with a ′, for example, the following relationship applies if only the variable Xj is reversed, then q ′ j = q (X ′ j = 1) = q (1 − Xj = 1) = 1 − qj. Since αij = eWij − 1 and here W ′ ij = − Wij, the following relationship applies when one end of an edge is reversed, α ′ ij ² when the constant is reversed.

referenceMentions.context: Computing Z belongs to the class of counting problems #P (Valiant, 1979).
Further, exact marginal inference is NP-hard (Cooper, 1990).
The MAP problem is typically easier, yet is still NP-hard (Shimony, 1994), even to approximate (Abdelbar & Hedetniemi, 1998).

One popular method is to use a message-passing algorithm called belief propagation (Pearl, 1988), which returns an exact solution in linear time in n, the number of variables, if the topology of the model is a tree.

If this method is applied to general topologies, termed loopy belief propagation (LBP), results are sometimes strikingly good (McEliece et al., 1998; Murphy et al., 1999), though in general it may not converge at all, and if it does, it may not be to a global optimum.

If this method is applied to general topologies, termed loopy belief propagation (LBP), results are sometimes strikingly good (McEliece et al., 1998; Murphy et al., 1999), though in general it may not converge at all, and if it does, it may not be to a global optimum.

(Yedidia et al., 2001) showed a remarkable connection between LBP and an earlier approach from statistical physics (Bethe, 1935; Peierls & Born, 1936), in that any fixed point of LBP corresponds to a stationary point of a function of the system, termed the Bethe free energy F .

, 2001) showed a remarkable connection between LBP and an earlier approach from statistical physics (Bethe, 1935; Peierls & Born, 1936), in that any fixed point of LBP corresponds to a stationary point of a function of the system, termed the Bethe free energy F .
Another interesting example is the demonstration (Chandrasekaran et al., 2011) that the Bethe approximation is very useful to count independent sets of a graph.

Extensive analysis has focused on understanding conditions under which LBP is guaranteed to converge to the global optimum (Heskes, 2004; Mooij & Kappen, 2007; Watanabe, 2011), but outside these restricted settings, until recently, there were no polynomial time methods even to approximate ZB .

Extensive analysis has focused on understanding conditions under which LBP is guaranteed to converge to the global optimum (Heskes, 2004; Mooij & Kappen, 2007; Watanabe, 2011), but outside these restricted settings, until recently, there were no polynomial time methods even to approximate ZB .
Further, it is possible to convert a general MRF into an equivalent binary pairwise model (Yedidia et al., 2001), though potentially with a much enlarged state space.

An algorithm was introduced in (Shin, 2012) guaranteed to return an approximately stationary point of F in polynomial time for such binary pairwise models, though with a bound on the maximum degree, ∆ = O(log n).
Interestingly, (Ruozzi, 2012) recently proved that ZB ≤ Z for attractive models.

Similarly, for graphical models whose partition function is the permanent of a non-negative matrix, ZB is recoverable via convex optimization and, here too, ZB ≤ Z (Huang & Jebara, 2009; Vontobel, 2010; Watanabe & Chertkov, 2010; Gurvits, 2011).

Similarly, for graphical models whose partition function is the permanent of a non-negative matrix, ZB is recoverable via convex optimization and, here too, ZB ≤ Z (Huang & Jebara, 2009; Vontobel, 2010; Watanabe & Chertkov, 2010; Gurvits, 2011).
Computing ZB is at least PPAD or PLS-hard in general since it not only requires a fixed point but also the global minimizer (Shin, 2013; Daskalakis & Papadimitriou, 2011).
Methods such as CCCP (Yuille, 2002) or UPS (Teh & Welling, 2002) are guaranteed to converge to a local minimum of the Bethe free energy, but this may be far from the global optimum.
Theorem 1 (Submodularity for any discretization of an attractive model, (Weller & Jebara, 2013a) Theorem 8, (Korc et al., 2012)).

Either method can achieve striking results quickly, though MK is our preferred method5 - it considers cavity fields around each variable and determines the range of possible beliefs after iterating LBP, starting from any initial values; since any minimum of F corresponds to a fixed point of LBP (Yedidia et al., 2001), this bounds all minima.

If the initial model is fully attractive, then by Theorem 1 we obtain a submodular multi-label MAP problem which is solvable using graph cuts with worst case runtime O(N) = O(ǫ−3n3m3W ) (Schlesinger & Flach, 2006; Greig et al., 1989; Goldberg & Tarjan, 1988).
Since the resulting multi-label MAP inference problem is NP-hard in general (Shimony, 1994), it is helpful to minimize its size.

For a fully attractive model, the resulting MAP problem may be solved in time O(N) by graph cuts (Theorem 1, (Schlesinger & Flach, 2006; Greig et al., 1989; Goldberg & Tarjan, 1988)), so it is sensible to minimize N .
In general, this is NP-hard (Shimony, 1994).

If it happens that all cost functions are submodular (as is always the case if the initial model is fully attractive by Theorem 1), then as already noted, it may be solved efficiently using graph cut methods, which rely on solving a max flow/min cut problem on a related graph, with worst case runtime O(N) (Schlesinger & Flach, 2006; Greig et al., 1989; Goldberg & Tarjan, 1988).
Alternatively, the topological restriction of bounded treewidth allows tractable inference (Pearl, 1988).
Further, under mild assumptions, this was shown to be the only restriction which will allow efficient inference for any cost functions (Chandrasekaran et al., 2008).

A recent approach reducing MAP inference to identifying a maximum weight stable set in a derived weighted graph ((Jebara, 2013), (Weller & Jebara, 2013b)) shows promise, allowing efficient inference if the derived graph is perfect.
Further, testing if this graph is perfect can be performed in polynomial time ((Jebara, 2013), (Chudnovsky et al.
Many different methods are available, see (Kappes et al., 2013) for a recent survey.
MQPBO (Kohli et al., 2008) and Kovtun’s method (Kovtun, 2003) are examples of this class.
, 2008) and Kovtun’s method (Kovtun, 2003) are examples of this class.
We aim to predict transformer failures in a power network (Rudin et al., 2012).
Our goal is to compute the marginal probability of failure of each transformer within the network (not simply in isolation as in (Rudin et al., 2012)).

We attempted to run BP using the libDAI package (Mooij, 2010) but were unable to achieve convergence, even with multiple initial values, using various sequential or parallel settings and with damping.

Interesting avenues include using it as a subroutine in a dual decomposition approach to optimize over a tighter relaxation of the marginal polytope, and it provides the opportunity to examine rigorously the performance of other Bethe approaches that typically run more quickly, such as LBP or CCCP (Yuille, 2002), against the true Bethe global optimum.

metadata.abstractText: When belief propagation (BP) converges, it does so to a stationary point of the Bethe free energy F , and is often strikingly accurate. However, it may converge only to a local optimum or may not converge at all. An algorithm was recently introduced for attractive binary pairwise MRFs which is guaranteed to return an ǫ-approximation to the global minimum of F in polynomial time provided the maximum degree ∆ = O(log n), where n is the number of variables. Here we significantly improve this algorithm and derive several results including a new approach based on analyzing first derivatives of F , which leads to performance that is typically far superior and yields a fully polynomial-time approximation scheme (FPTAS) for attractive models without any degree restriction. Further, the method applies to general (non-attractive) models, though with no polynomial time guarantee in this case, leading to the important result that approximating log of the Bethe partition function, logZB = −minF , for a general model to additive ǫaccuracy may be reduced to a discrete MAP inference problem. We explore an application to predicting equipment failure on an urban power network and demonstrate that the Bethe approximation can perform well even when BP fails to converge.
